abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Inland Waters Project
            for Croatia were as follows: outcomes were moderately
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was low or
            negligible, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was satisfactory.
            Some lessons learned included: political support is critical
            for these types of projects. Municipalities and elected
            mayors and council members had to make tough choices on
            tariff adjustments and enforce connections. Absence that
            support, implementation can be delayed and utility
            performance minimal. Political commitment must also be
            sustained at the central level to implement reforms to move
            the sector towards European Union (EU) compliance. It is
            important for Croatian Waters (HV) and the Ministry of
            Agriculture (MoA) to maintain strong capacity, a clear
            sector vision, and to sustain their commitment to
            agglomerate utilities. While some utilities had the capacity
            to implement, engage beneficiaries, and supervise the works
            effectively, others required considerable support from HV.
            In the weakest utilities works were delayed. This indicates
            that a further concentration of utilities will not only
            foster financial but also technical efficiency. The Project
            Implementation Unit (PIU) took some risk in selecting
            financially weaker and less capable utilities, but the
            investment and payoff proved worthwhile. The location of the
            task team leader and operations officer in Croatia and
            Central Europe helped the project advance at critical
            moments. This was especially the case in the final years of
            project implementation.
